Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT15-COX 
    

 UPDATE      UPDATE
      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR FRIDAY, SEPT. 15, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Eds. Adds: REVIEW-BAIT, OLY-1980;

   Deletes: CAR-NASCAR-SAFETY, GORE-COSTS, MOVIES-CIRCUS

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   OLYMPICS/SETTING UP OPENING DAY

   OLY-OPEN _ SYDNEY _ Complete viewer's guide to the Opening
Ceremony. Scene by scene explainer of the highlights. Will focus on
surprises and opening night energy. (Brock, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20.

   OLYMPICS-COSTAS _ ATLANTA _ Bob Costas, bright-eyed and bearing
tons of useful and not-so-useful information, will bound
kangaroo-like into our living rooms for a two-week visit beginning
tonight. As anchor of NBC's prime-time telecasts of the Summer
Olympics, Costas will spend 162 1/2 hours on the air, starting with
tonight's 4 1/2-hour coverage of the Opening Ceremony in Sydney.
This is his fourth Olympics for NBC and third as prime-time host.
It would not be stretching the truth to say he enjoys these
assignments quite a lot. His first love may be baseball, but the
Olympic Games get his blood pumping. (Holloway, Austin
American-Statesman)

   EDS: MOVED in (s) sports and (e) entertainment categories.

   OLY-PRIMER _ ATLANTA _ All about Oz: As the Olympics begin in
Sydney tonight, we offer a primer on things Australian, from A to
Z. (Auchmutey, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 39.

   COX EDs: This story is available via a Budget Tool WAN search
with a Location of Atlanta and a category of Lifestyle.

   OLY-TORCH _ SYDNEY _ Torch crosses the Harbor Bridge in Sydney.
(Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 8.

   OLY-ADVANCE _ SYDNEY _ Let the Games begin. General sports
advance. (Tierney, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 20.

   OLYWEATHER _ SYDNEY _ The cooler-than-Atlanta weather is great
for some sports, not so great for others. (Fish, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20.

   OLY-HUMMER _ SYDNEY _ Steve Hummer column, on gambling and the
Olympics. (Hummer, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). P16. ETA: 10 p.m.
EDT

   OLY-TRIATHLON _ SYDNEY _ Feature on Georgia's Sheila Taormina in
triathlon. (Rosen, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 16.

   OLYHOOP _ SYDNEY _ News/notes from basketball press conferences.
(Bunn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 12-14. ETA: 9 p.m. EDT.

   OLYSWIM _ SYDNEY _ News/notes from swimming press conference.
(Rosen, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 12.

   OLY-HALL _ SYDNEY _ Feature on swimmer Gary Hall, who attended
the University of Texas for one year and then turned pro. (Maher,
Austin American-Statesman).

   OLYTRACK _ SYDNEY _ Update from track and field. (Fish, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 12-14.

   OLYNOTE _ SYDNEY _ News and notes from Sydney. (Staff, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   OLY-ARCH _ Ohio's Wright State swimmer Leonard Ngoma who swims
for Zambia, came to the United States to swim after his parents
died in 1995 of malaria. ``There really was nothing for me,'' he
said. ``I wanted something more, but I didn't know where to turn.''
The International Olympic Committee _ which has a program to
nurture Olympians in under-developed nations _ soon provided a road
map. (Archdeacon, Dayton Daily News)

   OLY-ARCH-CRAIG _ Dante Craig, a boxer from Cincinnati who had
been working in a dry cleaners in Cincy when he got a second chance
at his dream. His brother dreamed that their dead mother spoke to
him and begged him to help Dante rekindle his boxing career.
(Archdeacon, Dayton Daily News)

   OLY-1980 _ As current Olympians look to the coming weeks and
dream of gold, some athletes are looking back: They were the
members of the 1980 Olympic team, and while the world competed in
Moscow, they stayed home. Twenty years later, they still grapple
with `what ifs.' (Belkin, Palm Beach Post)

   NATIONAL

   AIR-DELAYS _ WASHINGTON _ The Senate Commerce Committee holds a
hearing on the role of air traffic control in airline delays.
Witnesses include DOT Secretary Rodney Slater and Leo Mullin,
president and CEO of Delta. (Eversley, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   BUSH-DEBATE _ AUSTIN, Texas _ George W. Bush reaches an
agreement with Al Gore over debate schedule and gets absolutely no
concessions, portending another misstep by his campaign after a
series of misteps. (Herman, Austin American-Statesman) 6 p.m. 20-25

   CSX _ U.S. Rep. John Boehner met with CSX officials to get
action on

   problem crossings. (Weber, Hamilton News-Journal)

   BEAR-BITES-MAN _ Two archery hunters from Missouri suffered
minor injuries Wednesday during an attack by a black bear on Grand
Mesa. The two men, a father and son duo whose names were not
released, surprised the bear while walking in dense brush along
Buzzard Creek east of Vega Reservoir. (Grand Junction)

   ENVIRONMENT _ WASHINGTON _ A group of environmental and taxpayer
organizations Thursday called for reforms of the U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers to give greater civilian control over the agency and
impose independent reviews of major projects. The group said they'd
prefer that a pending water projects bill not pass Congress this
year unless it contains substantial Corps reforms, but that the
proposed Everglades restoration plan be adopted. (Lipman, Cox News
Service).

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Environment

   STEM-CELLS _ WASHINGTON _ Michael J. Fox and Mary Tyler Moore
testified before a Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Thursday
to support federal funding for stem cell research. (Doyle, Cox News
Service)

   WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government

   VOTER-POLL _ WASHINGTON _ The Brookings Institute holds a
briefing on a new survey of voter attitudes toward the candidates
and the issues. (Holmes, Cox News Service). 20.

   EDs: Moving on NYT wire in (w) Washington and (p) politics
categories.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category National, subcategory Politics.

   LIEBERMAN _ Like the loyal soldier he has pledged to be, Sen.
Joseph Lieberman (D-Conn.), the Democratic vice presidential
nominee, has reversed course on a number of issues on which he
differed with Vice President Al Gore. Among the most prominent:
Lieberman's unease with affirmative action, his support for making
it harder for Americans to sue and his belief that government
should use public funds to send children to private schools, at
least on an experimental basis. (Sherman, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 25

   WITH

   REBECCA-LIEBERMAN _ Rebecca Lieberman, daughter of vice
presidential nominee Joe Lieberman, is at FAU on behalf of the
Gore/Lieberman campaign. She's meeting with Florida Atlantic
University students for a roundtable discussion of financial aid
and other higher education issues and attending a meeting of the
Florida Atlantic University College Democrats. (Belkin, Palm Beach
Post).

   OHIO-SPRAWL - MIDDLETOWN, Ohio _ Southern Warren County
communities of Mason and Deerfield Township are among the nation's
worst examples of poorly planned suburban development, says the
Sierra Club in a national study of sprawl released Thursday
morning. (Pulse, Middleton Journal)

   FLOYD-MEMORIES _ GREENVILLE, N.C. _ The few people left on
Greenville's Eastern Street keep a close eye on the horizon,
watching for another Floyd. Every rain makes them nervous. The last
hurricane wiped out their neighborhood, leaving it to weeds and
slum lords. Now they are contemplating whether to stay or go.
(Greenville Daily Reflector). WITH PHOTOS.

   FLOYD-RECOVERY _ ROCKY MOUNT, N.C. _ Where are we? What do
people like Fred Turnage, Joe Durham, Norris Tolson, Charlie
Glazener and Jim Hunt see as the biggest challenges now? what have
we overcome so far? are we building back fast enough? where does
the area compare now in terms of where Grand Forks, N.D., was a
year after its flood? how long before the buyout process will be
complete? what, specifically, does the city plan to do with the
property that's condemned in that process? where will the
homeowners live then? (Rocky Mount Telegram)

   SAFE KIDS - Preview of conference, first of its kind, to build
strong families and keeping kids safe. Two-day seminar, starting
Sept. 18. Barbara Mandrell and mother of Len Bias will be there.
(Middletown Journal)

   HABITAT-MILESTONE _ Foremer president Jimmy Carter will be in
Americus, Ga., for completion of Habitat for Humanity's 100,000th
house worldwide Thursday. The organization will also claim that
affordable, decent housing is available in Sumter County, Ga., for
anyone who wants it. (Osinski, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 20.

   MCKINNEY _ WASHINGTON _ Many Americans might believe that
COINTELPRO, an acronym for the FBI's Counter Intelligence Program
that collected personal information on several civil rights
leaders, was a phenomenon of the 1960s and 1970s. But U.S. Rep.
Cynthia McKinney points a spotlight on similar federal government
programs that are alive today during next week's the annual
legislative meeting of the Congressional Black Caucus. (Eversley,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 6
p.m.

   INTERNATIONAL

   SUDAN-WATER _ The unquenchable loyalty of an Austin man to his
family and friends is bringing fresh water to a village in the
north of Sudan. Awad Abdelgadir, through his own fund raising
effort, persuaded Rotary International to donate the bulk of
$42,000 to build a water system for the village of Kolomiseed, on
the west bank of the Nile River about 200 miles south of the
Egyptian border. (Lisheron, Austin American-Statesman). 14. WITH
PHOTO.

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ There's something to be said for virtue. But,
given the goings-on along the campaign trail, maybe it's time to
rethink the glib cause-and-effect game politicians of both parties
play. (Tom Teepen is national correspondent for Cox Newspapers).
MOVED.

   JOEMURRAY-DREAMSVILLE _ Another in an occasional series of
Dispatches from Dreamsville columns: What Aunt Bert's shanty house
in Three Creeks, Ark., lacked in modern conveniences and upkeep, it
more than made up for in laughter and glee that became my salvation
while my dad was away at war. (Murray, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   ERNESTMURRAY-COLUMN _ LUFKIN, Texas _ I'm about to mark another
birthday. Note I didn't say celebrate. It just doesn't seem right
that I should celebrate something that comes along about as often
as a full moon. And besides, I don't feel (unintelligible) years
old. In fact, my wife told me the other day I reminded her of a
teen-ager. (Ernest Murray is managing editor of The Lufkin Daily
News) MOVED.

   BORDERS-COLUMN _ Cats can keep a yard free of most critters, but
forget about fending off armadillos. (Gary Borders is editor and
publisher of the Nacogdoches Daily Sentinel.) EMBARGOED for Sunday.
MOVED.

   GARCIA-COLUMN _ AUSTIN, Texas _ (Arnold Garcia is editorial page
editor of the Austin American-Statesman)

   MCNEELY-COLUMN _ AUSTIN, Texas _ pull from budget tool if not
too local. (McNeely, Austin American-Statesman)

   YOUNG-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ WACO, Texas _ Rats. Until a few
days ago the presidential campaign had been almost miraculously
issues-based. This week it is officially off-base. Tuesday the
``issue'' was subliminal rodents. Last week it was a caught-on-tape
vulgarity. And more and more we hear media recitation/speculation
about 30-second jabs. (John Young is opinion page editor of the
Waco Tribune-Herald) MOVED.

   BUSINESS

   AIR-DELAYS _ WASHINGTON _ The Senate Commerce Committee holds a
hearing on the role of air traffic control in airline delays.
Witnesses include Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater and Leo
Mullin, president and CEO of Delta Air Lines. (Eversley, Cox News
Service). 22.

   EDs: Moving on NYT wire in (w) Washington and (f) financial
categories.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category Business, subcategory
Transportation.

   FIRESTONE _ATLANTA _Firestone's tire recall will more than
double estimated third-quarter losses (50 to 60 cents a share) at
Allied Holding Inc, the Decatur-based car hauler said Thursday.

   The company hauls SUVs from three Ford plants, closed for three
weeks to make more tires available for the recall. (Grantham,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TECH-VISA _ For months, high-tech companies have been badgering
Congress to increase the number of visas granted to highly skilled
foreigners. Lawmakers now appear ready to act. But there may not be
time to pass a bill. So techies are hoping Congress will tack a
visa amendment onto an appropriations bill. Not pretty, but it
works. (Geewax, Cox News Service). 15.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category Business, subcategory
U.S.government

   OLY-STOCK _ Buying stock in a company because of its connection
to the Olympic Games is a risky way to pick investments, based on
the share price performance of companies that sponsored the 1996
games in Atlanta. Only two of the seven biggest sponsors have
outperformed the market since the Atlanta closing ceremonies on
Aug. 4, 1996: Scientific-Atlanta, up 871 percent, and Home Depot,
up 377 percent. (Walker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 18.

   ORKIN-VERDICT _ Atlanta-based Rollins Inc. says that a $80
million verdict in Alabama will have ''a material adverse impact''
on the company if not reduced. Artie Mae Jeter of Tuskegee had
alleged that Orkin, a unit of Rollins, hid extensive termite damage
to her home for at least 12 years. A memo from one Orkin executive
to another, written in 1988, confirmed that allegation. (Miller,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   E-BUSINESS _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting Business readers. Today: (Seward,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   AUTOMOTIVE NEWS

   COXNET WHEELS

   EDS: This is the CoxNet WHEELS page for the current week. This
layout is now available now. Art includes three color photographs.

   COXNET WHEELS 0912: 2000 FORD HARLEY-DAVIDSON F-150 _ Ford has
shown remarkable restraint with its Harley-Davidson F-150. It's a
Supercab that does stand out in any crowd, though, thanks to its
aggressive front end, chrome side pipes and monochromatic black
finish accentuated by Harley-Davidson orange pinstriping. (DeVault,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column color photo
of the 2000 Harley-Davidson F-150 and a 1-column color photo of the
truck's interior.

   WITH

   AT A GLANCE _ Fact box previewing the 2000 Harley-Davidson
F-150.

   SHARP DRIVING _ The tire crisis for Bridgestone/Firestone has
become a crisis for other tire manufacturers as well. As consumers
look for alternatives as replacement tires, other manufacturers
find that this windfall of sales has left them unable to respond to
the unexpected demand. (Sharp, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
Includes 1-column color photograph of columnist.

   SHARP-DRIVING _ ATLANTA _ After 2,600 miles with a Hummer, the
ultimate SUV, I'm not sure it qualifies as the ultimate
``all-terrain'' vehicle. Interstate highways are simply not its
forte. But who was to know? When the opportunity arose to take the
vehicle on an extended trip to Dubuque, Iowa, and Minneapolis, my
husband and I thought, ``Hey, cool!'' (Sharp, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   THE-MECHANIC _ Nora Carter's column will resume soon. (Carter,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   LIFESTYLE

   NOBRIDES _ In the cryptic prose of a classified ad, several
Atlantans are hawking their bridal gowns, an item of clothing some
women consider their most treasured possession. But look closer and
you'll find two words _ ``never worn'' _ which not only describe
the condition of the gowns, but hint at a larger story about the
owners, and perhaps the state of modern romance. (Harris, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 40.

   CONSUMER-COLUMN _ Jane Greig consumer column. (Greig, Austin
American-Statesman)

   MICKEY'S CLOSET _ A peek into Mickey's and Minnie's closets.
Staci Sturrock visits Disney World to talk fashion with those busy
Disney costumers. (Sturrock, Palm Beach Post).

   COXNET LIFESTYLES PAGE

   EDs: This is the CoxNet LIFESTYLES page for the current week.
This layout is now available now. Art includes several color photos

   Coxnet LIFESTYLES 0914: PRINCESSES OF POP _ They've been called
``teen-age Lolitas,'' ``preening bimbettes'' and ``jailbait
dynamos.'' They're the bubble gum-chewing, chart-topping teens who
have knocked such well-established female singers as Alanis
Morissette, Melissa Etheridge and Tori Amos off the charts. The
newest teen pop sensations are turning some heads, and not just for
their musical abilities. (Allmon, Waco Herald-Tribune)

   E-LIVING _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting arts, entertainment and leisure
activities. Today: (Footlick, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   PHISH _ Everything you've ever wanted to know about Phish, the
cult-fave band: Phish trivia, facts, books, set lists, etc. (Dayton
Daily News). 30. MOVED.

   DOCUDRAMAS _ A look at the turnaround time involved in taking
actual news and docudramaing it for TV use. Pegged to the new Elian
story on Fox Family this Sunday. (Kloer, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20.

   OLYMPICS-COSTAS _ ATLANTA _ Bob Costas, bright-eyed and bearing
tons of useful and not-so-useful information, will bound
kangaroo-like into our living rooms for a two-week visit beginning
tonight. As anchor of NBC's prime-time telecasts of the Summer
Olympics, Costas will spend 162 1/2 hours on the air, starting with
tonight's 4 1/2-hour coverage of the Opening Ceremony in Sydney.
This is his fourth Olympics for NBC and third as prime-time host.
It would not be stretching the truth to say he enjoys these
assignments quite a lot. His first love may be baseball, but the
Olympic Games get his blood pumping. (Holloway, Austin
American-Statesman)

   EDS: MOVED in (s) sports and (e) entertainment categories.

   MOVIE NEWS AND REVIEWS

   MOVIES-AFFAIR _ Movie review: ``An Affair of Love.'' Grade: B+.
(Ringel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 13.

   MOVIES-BAIT _ Review of the Jamie Foxx action movie ``Bait.''
Grade: B-. (Ringel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   MOVIES-DUETS _ Movie Review: ``Duets'' Gwyneth Paltrow sings.
Grade: D. (Ringel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   REVIEW-BAIT_ Movie review, ``Bait'' starring Jamie Foxx.
(Hamilton News-Journal)

   MOVIES-EDEN _ Review of independent film ``A Piece of Eden.''
Grade: B-. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 11.

   MOVIES-FAMOUS _ Movie review: ``Almost Famous.'' Cameron Crowe
rock tour film. Grade: A-. (Ringel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
26.

   MOVIES-IDIOTS _ Review of the Danish film ``The Idiots'' by the
director of ``Breaking the Waves.'' Grade: C+. (Murray, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 14.

   MOVIES-SOLOMON _ Review of foreign film ``Solomon &Gaenor.''
GRADE: C+. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 10.

   MOVIES-MINIREVIEWS _ Mini reviews of all currently playing
movies. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   SCIENCE-MEDICINE

   GAY-BLOOD-DONORS _ An FDA advisory panel will take up a
controversial issue on Friday: Whether gay men _ banned from
donating blood if they've had sex with a male since 1977 _ might be
allowed to donate. The development of improved AIDS tests and a
recent rise in HIV cases among heterosexuals is leading officials
to reconsider the ban. The advisory panel is likely to vote on the
issue Friday, and the FDA usually accepts advisory panel
recommendations. We'll talk to metro Atlanta gay activists, AID
Atlanta and local blood banks. (Staples, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20.

   HIGHLIGHTS-MEYERS _ AUSTIN, Texas _ If you ask Jack Myers a
question, you'll likely be met with silence. As senior science
editor at Highlights for Children magazine, his job is to answer
queries, but he never purports to know all the answers. Instead, he
pauses. Mentally chews on words, thoughts, ideas. Thinks about what
to say, how to say it, why it's so. And then, just as you think he
didn't hear you, or perhaps doesn't know, he delivers an answer.
(Barchas, Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   SPORTS

   FOOTBALL/PROS

   FBN-BESTBETS _ A look ahead and this weekend's NFL highlights to
come. (Seguira, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 20.

   FBN-CHUCK-SMITH _ Chuck Smith. After spending his first eight
seasons in the NFL with the Falcons, he signed with Carolina in the
offseason, part of the Panthers' attempt to upgrade its pass rush.
He's looking forward to Game 1 vs. the Falcons on Sunday.
(Winkeljohn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 18.

   FOOTBALL/COLLEGES

   FBC-WOODY-HAYES _ OXFORD, Ohio _ Woody Hayes. Mention the name,
and you've conjured up vivid images of a man with a passion for
college football. Images of Heisman Trophy running backs and clouds
of dust, of Rose Bowls and national championship celebrations, of a
gentle man with an explosive temper. Mention the name, and you're
likely to start an argument. (Conrad, Hamilton Journal News) MOVED
WEDNESDAY.

   FBC-HALLIBURTON _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Column on Hodges Mitchell, who
is pound for pound the best football player for the Longhorns. He
can do it all     run, catch, block, even return punts, but people
still grumble about the Longhorns running game. Hodges doesn't
deserve the grumbling. (Austin American-Statesman)

   E-SPORTS _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting Sports fans. Today: (Greene,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EDT and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   INTERNET LINKS

   For research purposes, or to publish in your paper for readers
who'd like more information, Internet links to some of the stories
on this budget are available daily on the Cox Intranet at
http://web.coxnews.net/NRS/NTAGS/NTAGWEEK.HTM

   FEATURES MATERIAL

   So specialty editors can focus on one day's budget, CoxNet
produces themed features budgets each day. Here is the schedule:

   Monday for Tuesday: Technology

   Tuesday for Wednesday: Automotive, personal finance and home &
garden

   Wednesday for Thursday: Food, CD reviews, video reviews

   TODAY: Movie reviews, travel, books and fashion

   Friday for Saturday: Religion and science & health

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.

   Night news editor is Todd C. Duncan, 404-526-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com.

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
Text:
For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Eds. Adds: REVIEW-BAIT, OLY-1980;

   Deletes: CAR-NASCAR-SAFETY, GORE-COSTS, MOVIES-CIRCUS

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

Journal-Constitution). 20.

Olympic Games get his blood pumping. (Holloway, Austin
American-Statesman)

Sydney tonight, we offer a primer on things Australian, from A to
Z. (Auchmutey, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 39.

   COX EDs: This story is available via a Budget Tool WAN search
with a Location of Atlanta and a category of Lifestyle.

(Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 8.

   OLY-ADVANCE _ SYDNEY _ Let the Games begin. General sports

   OLYWEATHER _ SYDNEY _ The cooler-than-Atlanta weather is great
for some sports, not so great for others. (Fish, Atlanta

   OLY-HUMMER _ SYDNEY _ Steve Hummer column, on gambling and the
Olympics. (Hummer, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). P16. ETA: 10 p.m.
EDT

   OLY-TRIATHLON _ SYDNEY _ Feature on Georgia's Sheila Taormina in
triathlon. (Rosen, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 16.

   OLYHOOP _ SYDNEY _ News/notes from basketball press conferences.
(Bunn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 12-14. ETA: 9 p.m. EDT.

(Rosen, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 12.

   OLY-HALL _ SYDNEY _ Feature on swimmer Gary Hall, who attended

   OLYTRACK _ SYDNEY _ Update from track and field. (Fish, Atlanta

   OLYNOTE _ SYDNEY _ News and notes from Sydney. (Staff, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

(Archdeacon, Dayton Daily News)

   NATIONAL

   AIR-DELAYS _ WASHINGTON _ The Senate Commerce Committee holds a
hearing on the role of air traffic control in airline delays.
Witnesses include DOT Secretary Rodney Slater and Leo Mullin,
president and CEO of Delta. (Eversley, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

agreement with Al Gore over debate schedule and gets absolutely no

series of misteps. (Herman, Austin American-Statesman) 6 p.m. 20-25

   CSX _ U.S. Rep. John Boehner met with CSX officials to get
action on

   problem crossings. (Weber, Hamilton News-Journal)

   BEAR-BITES-MAN _ Two archery hunters from Missouri suffered
minor injuries Wednesday during an attack by a black bear on Grand
Mesa. The two men, a father and son duo whose names were not
released, surprised the bear while walking in dense brush along
Buzzard Creek east of Vega Reservoir. (Grand Junction)

   ENVIRONMENT _ WASHINGTON _ A group of environmental and taxpayer
organizations Thursday called for reforms of the U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers to give greater civilian control over the agency and
impose independent reviews of major projects. The group said they'd
prefer that a pending water projects bill not pass Congress this
year unless it contains substantial Corps reforms, but that the
proposed Everglades restoration plan be adopted. (Lipman, Cox News
Service).

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Environment

   STEM-CELLS _ WASHINGTON _ Michael J. Fox and Mary Tyler Moore
testified before a Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Thursday
to support federal funding for stem cell research. (Doyle, Cox News
Service)

   WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government

   VOTER-POLL _ WASHINGTON _ The Brookings Institute holds a
briefing on a new survey of voter attitudes toward the candidates
and the issues. (Holmes, Cox News Service). 20.

   EDs: Moving on NYT wire in (w) Washington and (p) politics
categories.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category National, subcategory Politics.

   LIEBERMAN _ Like the loyal soldier he has pledged to be, Sen.
Joseph Lieberman (D-Conn.), the Democratic vice presidential
nominee, has reversed course on a number of issues on which he
differed with Vice President Al Gore. Among the most prominent:
Lieberman's unease with affirmative action, his support for making
it harder for Americans to sue and his belief that government
should use public funds to send children to private schools, at
least on an experimental basis. (Sherman, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 25

   WITH

   REBECCA-LIEBERMAN _ Rebecca Lieberman, daughter of vice
presidential nominee Joe Lieberman, is at FAU on behalf of the
Gore/Lieberman campaign. She's meeting with Florida Atlantic
University students for a roundtable discussion of financial aid
and other higher education issues and attending a meeting of the
Florida Atlantic University College Democrats. (Belkin, Palm Beach
Post).

   OHIO-SPRAWL - MIDDLETOWN, Ohio _ Southern Warren County
communities of Mason and Deerfield Township are among the nation's
worst examples of poorly planned suburban development, says the
Sierra Club in a national study of sprawl released Thursday
morning. (Pulse, Middleton Journal)

   FLOYD-MEMORIES _ GREENVILLE, N.C. _ The few people left on
Greenville's Eastern Street keep a close eye on the horizon,
watching for another Floyd. Every rain makes them nervous. The last
hurricane wiped out their neighborhood, leaving it to weeds and
slum lords. Now they are contemplating whether to stay or go.
(Greenville Daily Reflector). WITH PHOTOS.

   FLOYD-RECOVERY _ ROCKY MOUNT, N.C. _ Where are we? What do
people like Fred Turnage, Joe Durham, Norris Tolson, Charlie
Glazener and Jim Hunt see as the biggest challenges now? what have
we overcome so far? are we building back fast enough? where does
the area compare now in terms of where Grand Forks, N.D., was a
year after its flood? how long before the buyout process will be
complete? what, specifically, does the city plan to do with the
property that's condemned in that process? where will the
homeowners live then? (Rocky Mount Telegram)

   SAFE KIDS - Preview of conference, first of its kind, to build
strong families and keeping kids safe. Two-day seminar, starting
Sept. 18. Barbara Mandrell and mother of Len Bias will be there.
(Middletown Journal)

   HABITAT-MILESTONE _ Foremer president Jimmy Carter will be in
Americus, Ga., for completion of Habitat for Humanity's 100,000th
house worldwide Thursday. The organization will also claim that
affordable, decent housing is available in Sumter County, Ga., for
anyone who wants it. (Osinski, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 20.

   MCKINNEY _ WASHINGTON _ Many Americans might believe that
COINTELPRO, an acronym for the FBI's Counter Intelligence Program
that collected personal information on several civil rights
leaders, was a phenomenon of the 1960s and 1970s. But U.S. Rep.
Cynthia McKinney points a spotlight on similar federal government
programs that are alive today during next week's the annual
legislative meeting of the Congressional Black Caucus. (Eversley,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 6
p.m.

   INTERNATIONAL

   SUDAN-WATER _ The unquenchable loyalty of an Austin man to his
family and friends is bringing fresh water to a village in the
north of Sudan. Awad Abdelgadir, through his own fund raising
effort, persuaded Rotary International to donate the bulk of
$42,000 to build a water system for the village of Kolomiseed, on
the west bank of the Nile River about 200 miles south of the
Egyptian border. (Lisheron, Austin American-Statesman). 14. WITH
PHOTO.

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ There's something to be said for virtue. But,
given the goings-on along the campaign trail, maybe it's time to
rethink the glib cause-and-effect game politicians of both parties
play. (Tom Teepen is national correspondent for Cox Newspapers).
MOVED.

   JOEMURRAY-DREAMSVILLE _ Another in an occasional series of
Dispatches from Dreamsville columns: What Aunt Bert's shanty house
in Three Creeks, Ark., lacked in modern conveniences and upkeep, it
more than made up for in laughter and glee that became my salvation
while my dad was away at war. (Murray, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   ERNESTMURRAY-COLUMN _ LUFKIN, Texas _ I'm about to mark another
birthday. Note I didn't say celebrate. It just doesn't seem right
that I should celebrate something that comes along about as often
as a full moon. And besides, I don't feel (unintelligible) years
old. In fact, my wife told me the other day I reminded her of a
teen-ager. (Ernest Murray is managing editor of The Lufkin Daily
News) MOVED.

   BORDERS-COLUMN _ Cats can keep a yard free of most critters, but
forget about fending off armadillos. (Gary Borders is editor and
publisher of the Nacogdoches Daily Sentinel.) EMBARGOED for Sunday.
MOVED.

   GARCIA-COLUMN _ AUSTIN, Texas _ (Arnold Garcia is editorial page
editor of the Austin American-Statesman)

   MCNEELY-COLUMN _ AUSTIN, Texas _ pull from budget tool if not
too local. (McNeely, Austin American-Statesman)

   YOUNG-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ WACO, Texas _ Rats. Until a few
days ago the presidential campaign had been almost miraculously
issues-based. This week it is officially off-base. Tuesday the
``issue'' was subliminal rodents. Last week it was a caught-on-tape
vulgarity. And more and more we hear media recitation/speculation
about 30-second jabs. (John Young is opinion page editor of the
Waco Tribune-Herald) MOVED.

   BUSINESS

   AIR-DELAYS _ WASHINGTON _ The Senate Commerce Committee holds a
hearing on the role of air traffic control in airline delays.
Witnesses include Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater and Leo
Mullin, president and CEO of Delta Air Lines. (Eversley, Cox News
Service). 22.

   EDs: Moving on NYT wire in (w) Washington and (f) financial
categories.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category Business, subcategory
Transportation.

   FIRESTONE _ATLANTA _Firestone's tire recall will more than
double estimated third-quarter losses (50 to 60 cents a share) at
Allied Holding Inc, the Decatur-based car hauler said Thursday.

   The company hauls SUVs from three Ford plants, closed for three
weeks to make more tires available for the recall. (Grantham,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TECH-VISA _ For months, high-tech companies have been badgering
Congress to increase the number of visas granted to highly skilled
foreigners. Lawmakers now appear ready to act. But there may not be
time to pass a bill. So techies are hoping Congress will tack a
visa amendment onto an appropriations bill. Not pretty, but it
works. (Geewax, Cox News Service). 15.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category Business, subcategory
U.S.government

   OLY-STOCK _ Buying stock in a company because of its connection
to the Olympic Games is a risky way to pick investments, based on
the share price performance of companies that sponsored the 1996
games in Atlanta. Only two of the seven biggest sponsors have
outperformed the market since the Atlanta closing ceremonies on
Aug. 4, 1996: Scientific-Atlanta, up 871 percent, and Home Depot,
up 377 percent. (Walker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 18.

   ORKIN-VERDICT _ Atlanta-based Rollins Inc. says that a $80
million verdict in Alabama will have ''a material adverse impact''
on the company if not reduced. Artie Mae Jeter of Tuskegee had
alleged that Orkin, a unit of Rollins, hid extensive termite damage
to her home for at least 12 years. A memo from one Orkin executive
to another, written in 1988, confirmed that allegation. (Miller,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   E-BUSINESS _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting Business readers. Today: (Seward,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   COXNET WHEELS 0912: 2000 FORD HARLEY-DAVIDSON F-150 _ Ford has
shown remarkable restraint with its Harley-Davidson F-150. It's a
Supercab that does stand out in any crowd, though, thanks to its
aggressive front end, chrome side pipes and monochromatic black
finish accentuated by Harley-Davidson orange pinstriping. (DeVault,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column color photo
of the 2000 Harley-Davidson F-150 and a 1-column color photo of the
truck's interior.

   WITH

   AT A GLANCE _ Fact box previewing the 2000 Harley-Davidson
F-150.

   SHARP DRIVING _ The tire crisis for Bridgestone/Firestone has
become a crisis for other tire manufacturers as well. As consumers
look for alternatives as replacement tires, other manufacturers
find that this windfall of sales has left them unable to respond to
the unexpected demand. (Sharp, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
Includes 1-column color photograph of columnist.

   SHARP-DRIVING _ ATLANTA _ After 2,600 miles with a Hummer, the
ultimate SUV, I'm not sure it qualifies as the ultimate
``all-terrain'' vehicle. Interstate highways are simply not its
forte. But who was to know? When the opportunity arose to take the
vehicle on an extended trip to Dubuque, Iowa, and Minneapolis, my
husband and I thought, ``Hey, cool!'' (Sharp, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   THE-MECHANIC _ Nora Carter's column will resume soon. (Carter,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   LIFESTYLE

   NOBRIDES _ In the cryptic prose of a classified ad, several
Atlantans are hawking their bridal gowns, an item of clothing some
women consider their most treasured possession. But look closer and
you'll find two words _ ``never worn'' _ which not only describe
the condition of the gowns, but hint at a larger story about the
owners, and perhaps the state of modern romance. (Harris, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 40.

   CONSUMER-COLUMN _ Jane Greig consumer column. (Greig, Austin
American-Statesman)

   MICKEY'S CLOSET _ A peek into Mickey's and Minnie's closets.
Staci Sturrock visits Disney World to talk fashion with those busy
Disney costumers. (Sturrock, Palm Beach Post).

   COXNET LIFESTYLES PAGE

   EDs: This is the CoxNet LIFESTYLES page for the current week.
This layout is now available now. Art includes several color photos

   Coxnet LIFESTYLES 0914: PRINCESSES OF POP _ They've been called
``teen-age Lolitas,'' ``preening bimbettes'' and ``jailbait
dynamos.'' They're the bubble gum-chewing, chart-topping teens who
have knocked such well-established female singers as Alanis
Morissette, Melissa Etheridge and Tori Amos off the charts. The
newest teen pop sensations are turning some heads, and not just for
their musical abilities. (Allmon, Waco Herald-Tribune)

   E-LIVING _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting arts, entertainment and leisure
activities. Today: (Footlick, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   PHISH _ Everything you've ever wanted to know about Phish, the
cult-fave band: Phish trivia, facts, books, set lists, etc. (Dayton
Daily News). 30. MOVED.

   DOCUDRAMAS _ A look at the turnaround time involved in taking
actual news and docudramaing it for TV use. Pegged to the new Elian
story on Fox Family this Sunday. (Kloer, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20.

   OLYMPICS-COSTAS _ ATLANTA _ Bob Costas, bright-eyed and bearing
tons of useful and not-so-useful information, will bound
kangaroo-like into our living rooms for a two-week visit beginning
tonight. As anchor of NBC's prime-time telecasts of the Summer
Olympics, Costas will spend 162 1/2 hours on the air, starting with
tonight's 4 1/2-hour coverage of the Opening Ceremony in Sydney.
This is his fourth Olympics for NBC and third as prime-time host.
It would not be stretching the truth to say he enjoys these
assignments quite a lot. His first love may be baseball, but the
Olympic Games get his blood pumping. (Holloway, Austin
American-Statesman)

   EDS: MOVED in (s) sports and (e) entertainment categories.

   SCIENCE-MEDICINE

   GAY-BLOOD-DONORS _ An FDA advisory panel will take up a
controversial issue on Friday: Whether gay men _ banned from
donating blood if they've had sex with a male since 1977 _ might be
allowed to donate. The development of improved AIDS tests and a
recent rise in HIV cases among heterosexuals is leading officials
to reconsider the ban. The advisory panel is likely to vote on the
issue Friday, and the FDA usually accepts advisory panel
recommendations. We'll talk to metro Atlanta gay activists, AID
Atlanta and local blood banks. (Staples, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20.

   HIGHLIGHTS-MEYERS _ AUSTIN, Texas _ If you ask Jack Myers a
question, you'll likely be met with silence. As senior science
editor at Highlights for Children magazine, his job is to answer
queries, but he never purports to know all the answers. Instead, he
pauses. Mentally chews on words, thoughts, ideas. Thinks about what
to say, how to say it, why it's so. And then, just as you think he
didn't hear you, or perhaps doesn't know, he delivers an answer.
(Barchas, Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

He's looking forward to Game 1 vs. the Falcons on Sunday.

   FBC-WOODY-HAYES _ OXFORD, Ohio _ Woody Hayes. Mention the name,
and you've conjured up vivid images of a man with a passion for
college football. Images of Heisman Trophy running backs and clouds
of dust, of Rose Bowls and national championship celebrations, of a
gentle man with an explosive temper. Mention the name, and you're
likely to start an argument. (Conrad, Hamilton Journal News) MOVED
WEDNESDAY.

   FBC-HALLIBURTON _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Column on Hodges Mitchell, who

can do it all     run, catch, block, even return punts, but people
still grumble about the Longhorns running game. Hodges doesn't
deserve the grumbling. (Austin American-Statesman)
